trans-unit.source: How to choose parameters to optimize your algorithms in Azure Machine Learning | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to choose parameters to optimize your algorithms in Azure Machine Learning | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Explains how to choose the optimal parameter set for an algorithm in Azure Machine Learning.
trans-unit.target: Explains how to choose the optimal parameter set for an algorithm in Azure Machine Learning.

trans-unit.source: How to choose parameters to optimize your algorithms in Azure Machine Learning
trans-unit.target: How to choose parameters to optimize your algorithms in Azure Machine Learning

trans-unit.source: This topic describes how to choose the right hyperparameter set for an algorithm in Azure Machine Learning.
trans-unit.target: This topic describes how to choose the right hyperparameter set for an algorithm in Azure Machine Learning.

trans-unit.source: Most machine learning algorithms are dependent on various parameters.
trans-unit.target: Most machine learning algorithms are dependent on various parameters.

trans-unit.source: When we train a model, we need to provide values for those parameters.
trans-unit.target: When we train a model, we need to provide values for those parameters.

trans-unit.source: The efficacy of the trained model is dependent on the model parameters that we choose.
trans-unit.target: The efficacy of the trained model is dependent on the model parameters that we choose.

trans-unit.source: The process of finding out the optimal set of parameters is known as model selection.
trans-unit.target: The process of finding out the optimal set of parameters is known as model selection.

trans-unit.source: There are various ways in which model selection can be done.
trans-unit.target: There are various ways in which model selection can be done.

trans-unit.source: In machine learning, cross-validation is one of the most widely used methods for model selection and it is the default model selection mechanism in Azure Machine Learning.
trans-unit.target: In machine learning, cross-validation is one of the most widely used methods for model selection and it is the default model selection mechanism in Azure Machine Learning.

trans-unit.source: Since both R and Python are supported by Azure Machine Learning, users can always implement their own model selection mechanism using either R or Python.
trans-unit.target: Since both R and Python are supported by Azure Machine Learning, users can always implement their own model selection mechanism using either R or Python.

trans-unit.source: There are four steps in the process of finding the best parameter set.
trans-unit.target: There are four steps in the process of finding the best parameter set.

trans-unit.source: **Define parameter space**: For the algorithm, we first decide the exact parameter values we would like to consider.
trans-unit.target: **Define parameter space**: For the algorithm, we first decide the exact parameter values we would like to consider.

trans-unit.source: **Define cross-validation settings**: For the dataset, we need to decide how to choose cross-validation folds.
trans-unit.target: **Define cross-validation settings**: For the dataset, we need to decide how to choose cross-validation folds.

trans-unit.source: **Define metric**: Then we decide what metric to use for determining the best set of parameters, e.g. accuracy, root mean squared error, precision, recall, or f-score.
trans-unit.target: **Define metric**: Then we decide what metric to use for determining the best set of parameters, e.g. accuracy, root mean squared error, precision, recall, or f-score.

trans-unit.source: **Train, evaluate and compare**: For each unique combination of the parameter values, cross-validation is carried out and based on the error metric defined by the user, the best performing model can be chosen.
trans-unit.target: **Train, evaluate and compare**: For each unique combination of the parameter values, cross-validation is carried out and based on the error metric defined by the user, the best performing model can be chosen.

trans-unit.source: The following experiment shows how this can be achieved in Azure Machine Learning.
trans-unit.target: The following experiment shows how this can be achieved in Azure Machine Learning.

trans-unit.source: image1
trans-unit.target: image1

trans-unit.source: Define parameter space
trans-unit.target: Define parameter space

trans-unit.source: The parameter set can be defined at the model initialization step.
trans-unit.target: The parameter set can be defined at the model initialization step.

trans-unit.source: The parameter pane of all machine learning algorithms has two trainer modes – **Single Parameter** and **Parameter Range**.
trans-unit.target: The parameter pane of all machine learning algorithms has two trainer modes – **Single Parameter** and **Parameter Range**.

trans-unit.source: We need to choose the **Parameter Range** mode (Fig. 1).
trans-unit.target: We need to choose the **Parameter Range** mode (Fig. 1).

trans-unit.source: That enables entering multiple values for each parameter: comma-separated values can be entered into the text box.
trans-unit.target: That enables entering multiple values for each parameter: comma-separated values can be entered into the text box.

trans-unit.source: Alternately **Use Range Builder** can be used to define the maximum and minimum points of the grid and the total number of points to be generated.
trans-unit.target: Alternately **Use Range Builder** can be used to define the maximum and minimum points of the grid and the total number of points to be generated.

trans-unit.source: By default the parameter values are generated on a liner scale.
trans-unit.target: By default the parameter values are generated on a liner scale.

trans-unit.source: But if the **Log Scale** box is checked, then the values are generated in the log scale (i.e. the ratio of the adjacent points is constant instead of their difference).
trans-unit.target: But if the **Log Scale** box is checked, then the values are generated in the log scale (i.e. the ratio of the adjacent points is constant instead of their difference).

trans-unit.source: For integer parameters a range can be defined with a hyphen “-“, e.g. “1-10” which means all integers between 1 and 10 (both inclusive) will form the parameter set.
trans-unit.target: For integer parameters a range can be defined with a hyphen “-“, e.g. “1-10” which means all integers between 1 and 10 (both inclusive) will form the parameter set.

trans-unit.source: A mixed mode is also supported, e.g. “1-10, 20, 50”.
trans-unit.target: A mixed mode is also supported, e.g. “1-10, 20, 50”.

trans-unit.source: In this case in addition to integers 1-10, 20 and 50 will also be added to the parameter set.
trans-unit.target: In this case in addition to integers 1-10, 20 and 50 will also be added to the parameter set.

trans-unit.source: image2
trans-unit.target: image2

trans-unit.source: image3
trans-unit.target: image3

trans-unit.source: Cross-validation fold definition
trans-unit.target: Cross-validation fold definition

trans-unit.source: The [Partition and Sample][partition-and-sample] module can be used to assign folds to the data randomly.
trans-unit.target: The [Partition and Sample][partition-and-sample] module can be used to assign folds to the data randomly.

trans-unit.source: In the following figure, we see an example configuration for the module where we define 5 folds and randomly assign fold number to the sample instances.
trans-unit.target: In the following figure, we see an example configuration for the module where we define 5 folds and randomly assign fold number to the sample instances.

trans-unit.source: image4
trans-unit.target: image4

trans-unit.source: Define Metric
trans-unit.target: Define Metric

trans-unit.source: The [Sweep Parameters][sweep-parameters] module provides support for empirically choosing the best set of parameters for a given algorithm and dataset.
trans-unit.target: The [Sweep Parameters][sweep-parameters] module provides support for empirically choosing the best set of parameters for a given algorithm and dataset.

trans-unit.source: The properties pane of this module includes, in addition to other information regarding training the model, the metric to be used for determining the best parameter set.
trans-unit.target: The properties pane of this module includes, in addition to other information regarding training the model, the metric to be used for determining the best parameter set.

trans-unit.source: It has two different drop down lists for classification and regression algorithms, respectively.
trans-unit.target: It has two different drop down lists for classification and regression algorithms, respectively.

trans-unit.source: If the algorithm under consideration is a classification algorithm the regression metric is ignored and vice versa.
trans-unit.target: If the algorithm under consideration is a classification algorithm the regression metric is ignored and vice versa.

trans-unit.source: In this specific example, we chose **Accuracy** as the metric.
trans-unit.target: In this specific example, we chose **Accuracy** as the metric.

trans-unit.source: image5
trans-unit.target: image5

trans-unit.source: Train, evaluate and compare
trans-unit.target: Train, evaluate and compare

trans-unit.source: The same [Sweep Parameters][sweep-parameters] module trains all the models corresponding to the parameter set, evaluates various metrics and then outputs the best trained model based on the metric chosen by the user.
trans-unit.target: The same [Sweep Parameters][sweep-parameters] module trains all the models corresponding to the parameter set, evaluates various metrics and then outputs the best trained model based on the metric chosen by the user.

trans-unit.source: This module has two mandatory inputs
trans-unit.target: This module has two mandatory inputs

trans-unit.source: the untrained learner
trans-unit.target: the untrained learner

trans-unit.source: the dataset
trans-unit.target: the dataset

trans-unit.source: and an optional dataset input.
trans-unit.target: and an optional dataset input.

trans-unit.source: We connect the dataset with fold information to the mandatory dataset input.
trans-unit.target: We connect the dataset with fold information to the mandatory dataset input.

trans-unit.source: If the dataset is not assigned any fold information, then a 10 fold cross-validation is automatically executed by default.
trans-unit.target: If the dataset is not assigned any fold information, then a 10 fold cross-validation is automatically executed by default.

trans-unit.source: If the fold assignment is not done and a validation dataset is provided at the optional dataset port, then a train-test mode chosen and the first dataset is used to train the model for each parameter combination, and is then evaluated on the validation dataset.
trans-unit.target: If the fold assignment is not done and a validation dataset is provided at the optional dataset port, then a train-test mode chosen and the first dataset is used to train the model for each parameter combination, and is then evaluated on the validation dataset.

trans-unit.source: The left output port of the module shows different metrics as a function of parameter values.
trans-unit.target: The left output port of the module shows different metrics as a function of parameter values.

trans-unit.source: The right output port gives the trained model corresponding to the best performing model as per the metric chosen by the user (accuracy in this case).
trans-unit.target: The right output port gives the trained model corresponding to the best performing model as per the metric chosen by the user (accuracy in this case).

trans-unit.source: image6
trans-unit.target: image6

trans-unit.source: image7
trans-unit.target: image7

trans-unit.source: We can see the exact parameters chosen by visualizing the right output port.
trans-unit.target: We can see the exact parameters chosen by visualizing the right output port.

trans-unit.source: This model can be used in scoring a test set or in an operationalized web service after saving as a trained model.
trans-unit.target: This model can be used in scoring a test set or in an operationalized web service after saving as a trained model.

trans-unit.target: test
